posts.title: Vim mapping
posts.text: nmap nmap command is used to define mapping for Normal mode only. This grammar should be same as this: 1:namp v :version<cr> n stands for Normal mode; v is the new shortcut we want to set; :version is the default command we want to replace; <cr> is the Enter Key we need to press after the default. nunmap is used to remove the mapping for v. nmap is recursive, if as we mapped w to another action already, if we create mapping for a to w, a will execute the existing mapping behavior for w and not itâ€™s default behavior. I recommended you always use use non-recursive mappings, except if you actually need recursion. :map --> normal, visual, operator-pending :nmap --> normal :xmap --> visual :cmap --> command-line :omap --> operator-pending If you want to preview your current mappings for Normal mode, just run :nmap command For further information on this topic, run command :h mapping and :h key-notation.

posts.title: Vimä¸­çš„æœç´¢å’Œæ›¿æ¢
posts.text: Ranges For most Vim commands, the default range is the current line. However we can control ranges, and in that way execute commands over the custom range of liness or characters in the current buffer. :s/bad/good/g change all words bad to good in the current line. :6,11s/bad/good/g make the same change, but in lines 6 to 11, including 1 and 11 :%s/bag/good/g make the same change in the entire file. 28 line 28 1 line 1 $ last line % all line in a file (same as 1,)6,28line6to28inclusive11,) 6,28 line 6 to 28 inclusive 11,)6,28line6to28inclusive11, line 11 to end of the file .,$ current line to end of the file .+4 current line current+5 line, inclusive ?a?,/b between pattern a and b, inclusive Each search and replace can follow a flag, like g --> to replace all occurrences in the range; c --> to confirm each substitution; i --> ignore case; I --> mind case. If flag were not used, only the first occurrence in the range would be replaced. You can also in select the content first in Visual mode, then start typing the rest of substitution command. This sentence is short Above method search the strings instead of the whole word, if we want to replace only the whole word, use \<and\> to specify that only whole word should be matched. :s/\<is\>/was/g If you want to replace two different words with one new word, do this: :make :s/\(pretty\|good\)/awesome/gi the new character | in this command is logical or. c flag, you can interactive with each search and replace in Vim. 1:%s/bad/good/gc y or n makes you confirm one by one; a replace all remaining word; q simply quit the replacement process. l replace only the current word and terminate the replacement process. ^E = ctrl-e scroll up the screen; ^Y = ctrl-y scroll down the screen. :vimgrep warning *.md search â€˜warningâ€™ in all markdown files in the current directory. cmd function :cN jump to the next match :cN jump to the previous match :clist view all files that containe the matched string :cc <number> jump to the specific numbered file, which you get from :clist output :match ErrorMsg /<pattern>/ to highlight all matches of a string in your current buffer. In this way, you can change the color of the highlights, letâ€™s see what we have here. :match the command here we also have ErrorMsg -->red color WarningMsg --> pink color ModeMsg --> bold font MoreMsg --> green color the global command :g/error/d this will delete all lines in the current buffer which contain the pattern â€˜errorâ€™ character explanation g the command itself error the pattern we want to search d the Ex command delete(:d) If we want to all line not containing the string â€˜errorâ€™, we can run command this :g!/error/d If we want to delete all blank lines: :g/^\s*$/d, letâ€™s break down this command g --> the global command ^ --> the start of line \s* --> zero or more space characters $ --> the end of line d --> the Ex command delete

posts.title: VimåŸºç¡€
posts.text: Command Mode: This is the the default mode in which vim starts. We can use a variety of command in this mode like copy, paste, delete, replace and many more. Insert Mode: You can use this mode to enter/edit text. Command Line Mode: Command line mode is used to enter command. The commands start with a colon. Visual Mode: In this mode you can visually select text and run commands on selected section. Create and Open Files: Open terminal and run vim, after that, run command `:edit .. Editing: insert text is writing text before cursor, deletion is deleting after the cursor. there are some shortcuts for insert text. insert before cursor i insert at the begining of the line I insert at the end of the line A insert next by one position of the cursor a open a new line below the current line o open a new line above the current line O(capital letter o) delete the next letter and switch to insert mode s delete the current line and switch to insert modeS or cc. if you want to change text from the current cursor position C replace the next letter without switch to insert mode r replace the entire line R move cursor to the begining of the current line in command mode 0 move cursor to the end of the current line in command mode $ ctrl +f scroll down entire page. ctrl + b scroll up entrie page w move cursor to the begining of next word. b move cursor to the begining of last word. e move cursor to the end of the current world. :njump to the nth line. :0jump the start of file. :$jump to the start of the last sentence. Vim keeps track of your navigation using a jump list. You can go backward by ctrl+o, go forward by ctrl + i. Buffer: when we open a file, Vim load its contents from disk drive. When we edit a file, we are actually editing the file from buffer. When we finished editing and save file, that time only buffer contents are transferred to appropriate file. y copy single character from cursor position. p past character after cursor position. P past character before cursor positon. x delete character from cursor positon. X delete previous character from cursor position. dw delete word from cursor position D delete entire line from cursor positon. dd delete entire line Y`yycopy entire line To perform multi-line/multi-word actions just use numbers with command. to perform one time undo action excuteuto perform multiple undo action, use number withsame command. to undo all executeUto redoctr+rincremental search: when the user types text, one or more possible matches for the text are found and immediately presented to the user. to perform incremental search:set insearchyou can execute the following setting in command mode to custom you search settings::set hlsearchand:set incsearchor undo execute:set nohlsearchor:set noincsearchadd\cor\Cto set case sensitive.<search the words which include the letters at the begining of the word> search the words which include the letters at the end.

posts.title: vimè¯­è¨€
posts.text: Verbs Powerless verbs x delete character under the cursor to the right X delete character under the cursor to the left r replace character under the cursor with another character s delete character under the cursor and enter the Insert mode Powerful verbs y copy c change d delete v visually select Note: these commands are usually known as operators commands or operators. Modifiers i inner a around t searches for something within the current line, it only searches forwards, and locate cursor before the character you want to search. f same as t but locate cursor right on the character you want to search, this two modifiers will be very useful for locating cursor within current line. Nouns w,W start of next world or WORD b,B start of previous word or WORD e,E end of next word or WORD $ end of line 0 start of line s sentence p paragraph t tag(in context of HTML) b block(in context of programming) aw a(complete) word as a (complete) sentence ap a (complete) paragraph iw inner word is inner sentence ip inner paragraph dw delete word from cursor position to the end of the word cis change inside sentence ci" change insdie quote c/hello change search hello, change until next occurrence of hello ctY change until Y vap visually around paragraph dj delete down a line (current and below) dt) delete up until next closing parenthesis . the dot command will repeat the commands which change the contents of the buffer. If you want repeat a combination of movements and changes, you can record macro.

posts.text: +<linenumber> the cursor will be positioned on the specified line for the first file you open. 1vim +125 .vimrc +<string> the cursor will positioned on the first line containing the specified string in the first file you open. 1vim +Plug .vimrc +cmd the command â€˜cmdâ€™ will be executed after the first file has been read. Itâ€™s interpreted as the Ex command. 1vim +$ .vimrc -x use encryption to read or write files. 1vim -x .vimrc whenever youâ€™re not typing, itâ€™s better to get back to Normal mode. ctrl-o when you are in Insert mode, and press ctrl-o, you will enter Command mode, but after execute one command, you will be automatically sent back to Insert mode. d4w you will delete four words after your cursor. :e <filename> open a file in your current session. You entered a file, want to open another file, r newfile.txt insert new file below the cursor in current buffer. 0r newfile.txt insert new file before the first line. r!sed -n 2,8p newfile.txt insert lines 2 to 8 from newfile below the cursor. r !ls insert a directory listing below the cursor. ZZ Exit Vim but write only when changes have been made. qa Exit all opened files in current Vim session. sav newfilename.txt Save current buffer as a new file by new name. w,W,e,E,b,B 6j take you six lines below.3w take you to the start of the 3rd world next world. ctrl-d scroll down half page. ctrl-u scroll up half page. ctrl-f forwards down full page ctrl-b backwards up full page gg go to the top of the file G go to the bottom of the file 50% go to line at the 50% of the file :linenumber jump to line specified { go to the beginning of the current paragraph } go to the end of the current paragraph % go to the matching pair of (),[],{} H Move cursor to the highest line in current window M Move cursor to the middle line of the current window L Move cursor to the lowest line of the current window search forward / search backward ? nâ‡ŒN Place your cursor to any word, Press * Vim will search forwards for the next occurence of that word. Press # Vim will search backwards for the word under your cursor. but these two commands are searching for exact words, if you donâ€™t want exact word matching, use commands g* and g# accordingly. in Command mode, ctrl-o jump back to your previous position. ctrl-i jump forwards. place the cursor to any word you want to search. Press:/ then press ctrl-r and then ctrl-w, these will copy the word under cursor to the command line, ready for searching. Ex open current dir in current window. Ex <dir> open specified directory. :Sex open current dir in horizontal split window. :Vex open current dir in vertical split window. When you hit enter, it will open file in the original dir window. Lexplore open current dir in vertical split window, When you hit enter, it will open file in the original file window. :Tex open current dir in a new tab. You can change the dir listing view to show more or less information, change the sorting order or hide some kind of files. you can hit i to cycle through the view types. There are four of them: thin, long, wide and tree. Once you choose your favorite, set it to be defalut one in your .vimrc file, like: let g:netrw_liststyle = 3 vim /Users/ken with Vim, not only can you open files, but you can also open directories. D deletes the file under the cursor. R rename the file under the cursor. X executes the file under the cursor. % creates a new file in the current dir. Vim will ask you for a file name and open a new buffer. When you hit Enter to open a file, it will be opened in the same window as netrw, if you would like to keep the netrw in a side split, you can add let g:netrw_browe_split = 4. If youâ€™re not sure of your home directory location, runecho $HOME in Vim. :colorschemeã„© then press Tab you can choose the build-in scheme, once you find the color scheme you like, add it to .vimrc file:colorscheme <scheme_name> set cursorline mark the line the cursor is currently in. set cursorcolumn mark the current column of the cursor. :g or ctrl+g you can show detailed information about number of lines, words, characters, etc. in you current bufffer. You can press u in Normal mode to call undo command, if you want to undo multiple times, attach a digit prefix, for example 5u to undo the last 5 changes U undo all recent changes on the current line. ctrl-r youâ€™ll run the redo command. :earlier <digit> revert last changes :later <digit> redo last changes . earlier 2d undo changes in last 2 days . ea 3h undo changes in last 3 hours . ea 1m undo changes in last 1 minute lat 15s redo all the changes in last 15 seconds :earlier 3f undo last 3 file states(last 3 buffer writes) Vim creates an undo branch every time you hit u. The branch represents the state of the file before you execute undo. So you can use g-command to move backward or g+ to move forward between these branches. Vim supports persistent undo/redo, you can run undo/redo even from your previous sessions.

posts.title: vim shortcuts
posts.text: jump to the top of the file gg jump to the end of the file G $ vim +33 my_file.txt, the cursor will be positioned on the line 33 for the first file you open In Vim, the -c cmd option allows you to execute a command after the first file has been read. This can be useful for automating tasks or customizing Vimâ€™s behavior when opening a file. Hereâ€™s how you can use the -c cmd option in Vim: Open a file and run a command: You can open a file in Vim and run a command immediately after the file is loaded. For example, to open a file example.txt and jump to line 10, you can use the following command: vim -c "normal 10G" example.txt This command will open example.txt in Vim and move the cursor to line 10. Run multiple commands: You can also chain multiple commands using the -c option. Separate each command with a semicolon ;. For example, to open a file and set syntax highlighting to a specific type, you can use: vim -c "set syntax=python" -c "normal G" example.py This command will open example.py in Vim, set the syntax highlighting to Python, and move the cursor to the end of the file. Execute an Ex command: You can execute Ex commands (commands that start with ğŸ˜ƒ using the -c option. For example, to open a file and save it with a different name, you can use: â€‹ vim -c ":w newfile.txt" example.txt This command will open example.txt in Vim and save it as newfile.txt. Using the -c cmd option in Vim provides flexibility in automating tasks or customizing Vim's behavior when opening files. You can experiment with different commands to suit your specific requirements.

posts.title: Hello World
posts.text: Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub. Quick Start Create a new post 1$ hexo new "My New Post" More info: Writing Run server 1$ hexo server More info: Server Generate static files 1$ hexo generate More info: Generating Deploy to remote sites 1$ hexo deploy More info: Deployment
